number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												I have played many many games and very few of them offer the freedom, satisfaction, and fun that Dvinity: Original Sin brings to the table. Most modern RPGs are more action than RPG, and suffer from dumb downed and simplified gameplay to appeal to a broader audience. Well Divinity: Original Sin brings the depth and interaction of older series like Baldur's Gate as well as beautiful graphics and music that really brings the Dungeons and Dragons style genre to the next level. Quests require you to talk to various npcs, whose dialouges are always extraordinarily written, and read excerpts from journals and books to uncover plots and mysteries as well as unravel your tale as a Source Hunter. There are no quest markers or waypoints, which may leave you lost or searching for what to do next, but as you adjust and learn to put the pieces together you will find yourself immersed in the beautiful world, Every aspect of the game just feels so finely polished and well made. Dialouges with npcs are engaging and many times hilarous. The word intuitive is thrown around a lot for games, but the crafting system in Divinity definitely deserves it. I don't want to give too much away but one small example is you can take a knife to a pillow to get a feather, which can be combined with the same knife to create a quill which can be crafted into various other things. The world is extremely interactive, rivaling AAA titles like Skyrim with the ability to pick up and move around almost every object, including chests and barrels. The combat is turn-based, with each party member having a number of action points, determined by various stats, that are used to move, use skills, etc during combat. It is very tatical, and the environment plays a huge role. You can lay down oil, slowing your opponents and limiting their action points for a couple of turns, then even light the pool of oil on fire buring everyone standing in it. There are many combinations like this, such as making it rain then electrocuting and stunning opponents standing in the pool of water that forms. One of the big ways the combat stands out is that buffs and debuffs play a serious role in the combat. Being stunned, knocked, down, etc can take someone out of a fight for multiple turns, creating huge advantages. Fights are very tough, and you are almost always fighting someone a higher level than you are, so utilizing your skills correctly is key to a satisfying victory. You can also converse with the people in your party, discussing events and things that you've done. You also discuss with your party when making decisions for quests. There are multiple meters for how people percieve you, such as independent/dependent, heartless/compationate, bold/cautious, that change based on the decisions you make and things you say. The icing on the cake of Divinity: Original Sin is that all of this can be experienced with a friend. There is drop in/drop out co op that is super easy to use. You can split up control of your party amongst the two of you and set off on your adventure.I can not reccomend this game enough, especially to any who find themselves going waypoint to waypoint completing boring quests or easy mind numbing combat in other games. For casual gamers I would still recommend this game, but heed my warning that you may find yourself lost and not sure where to go next, or having difficulties in a tough fight. You can always turn the difficulty down though if you're having too much trouble. So get out there. Explore. Discover. Interact.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												YAY's:- Great combat mechanics; emphasis on abilities and terrain/objects interaction.- Beautiful graphics engine; vivid colors and nice particle effects.- Good lengthy storyline/dialog with a quirky sense of humor.- Excellent music, sound effects, and character voice-overs.- Hot-join 2-player coop; party members can be reassigned.- Dev studio that listens to the community and quickly patches.- Toolkit to develop your own mods.- Very limited player hand-holding (challenging enemies, no quest markers, no auto-crafting); may be a NAY for some?NAY's:- Interface (inventory management, spell bar, party grouping) is clunky.- Character and weapon/armor aesthetics are lacking in variety.- Requires a larger amount of customizable hotkeys.Divinity: Original Sin is a love letter to earlier cRPGs like Ultima 7 or Baldur's Gate. Player characters are completely customizable, not pigeon-holed to a specific class. You can build whatever combination you desire, though some builds may be more effective than others. Combat is turn-based and individual battles may take as long as 20 minutes to finish. Battles are tough as you will typically be outnumbered. However, taking time to learn the mechanics is very rewarding and you will finish each battle feeling like a tactical genius. The game can be played single-player but the coop experience is where the game really shines. A friend can join your game at any point and control any character(s) that you assign to him/her. Larian Studios have been really stellar in quickly releasing patches and hotfixes post-release. This developer deserves your money. Buy this game.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
2015
												Divinity: Original Sin is another masterful entry into the critically acclaimed Divinity Universe from the wonderful Larian Studios!Divinity: Original Sin follows in the footsteps of it's predecessors, throwing the player into a magnificiently crafted world full of character intrigue, mystery, betrayal and hope. The story plot is free-flowing, allowing for "maximum" freedom in the choices one can make (and although it works quite well at the best of times), it often requires moments of linear gameplay in order to avoid stalls, glitches, etc. The written script is intelligent, often subtle in humour and philosophy. Character customization is similiar to previous titles, allowing for the greatest degree of freedom in hybrid builds and mashups of class types. Combat takes a different turn, heading towards turn based battles - although free movement exists outside of combat. Again, almost all items in the game world can be stolen, found, bartered or sold. Crafting requires a solid memory, as the instructions for craftables are found within lore books, often in rhyme and poetry. Divinity boasts memorable characters, easter eggs and references (in one instance a solid, yet humourful, recommendation to buy Dragon Commander)...Original Sin's visuals are not spectacular, but unique and arresting to the eye. Colors are bright and vivid, spell effects are often satisfying, and character animations are smooth and fluent. The music of Original Sin is a fantastic element, as composer Kirill Pokrovsky comes aboard once more, delivering a beautiful, atmospheric soundtrack as befits the games style. The mechanics are well implemented and reactive, as you can create hazardous surfaces of fire, ice or slime with combinations of the elements. The content is satisfying (even the semi-pointless Golden Grail and Zandalors Trunks). The UI is simple to follow, the controls easy to master. Character voice overs are rare, but professional in tone and fluency of language. Multiplayer boasts an interesting concept of drop in/drop out gameplay, as the host of any game has complete control over the progression of all characters - only allowing for drop-in players to progress in the campaign, influencing little change over the character controlled.Divinity: Original Sin is a magnificient title from a wonderful developer, and is absolutely well worth the money and time for those who enjoy tactical RPG experiences with freedom of choice!

content:
er 12, 2014
												I have never played any of this series at all so I'm giving this review without the past tinting it in good or bad way for those that might not know anything about the game.  So I will give you with the bit I've played my first impressions with what I think is good and bad.Since I got it I haven't been able to get out of it... in a good way.  I'm totally addicted and found the game that suits me to the max.  This is turn based, so it gives me time to think without pressure yet still sitting on the edge of my seat at the fight.  It kind of threw me in the beginning though on character creation because I didn't know it was a duo... I was quite perplexed when I had to create two and customize them. (again I've never played any of the earlier ones so not even sure if that is how they worked in those)  But the whole two character thing had be curious right off the bat.  I figured it was basicly like a skyrim of a different flavor, story, etc etc.  But it isn't and it is!  For me, it's perfect.  It guides you along at the beginning yet gives you freedom to experiment and explore to start you out.  Perfectly balanced in my opinion for a brand new person.  They are great at the queues you need to not salp you in the face eyt pop up at the perfect time with suggestions.  They aren't obnoxious at all, but definitely letting you know about a new feature.I think it is an amazing and creative touch about the dialogs you have that affect the game between your two characters that you choose how it goes.  There are different options.   They really thought out of the box on this one.  I'm an animator for the film TV and gaming industries and not much impresses me. But this one did. the only negative thing I can say about it is the camera.  though it's not hard to get the hang at all on rotating it, they put a limit on it severely so you have to zoom in to see through walls at times, which is a feature of the game, not a bug.  It just messes up my immersion a wee bit, but i'm sure I will get used to it soon enough.  I just love the barter / selling / buying system a LOT.  items are as good as gold and visa versa.  it took me a couple times to realize I could switch between the characters in the same selling / bartering menu, but it's something that isn't hidden at all either.I could go on and on about it but in a nut shell, it's just amazing and I'm totally addicted and that is a huge feat to do with my line of work.Create an awesome day and kudos to the awesome creativity to the devs.  it is totally worth the price!~ ish

content:
6, 2014
												This game is downright amazing. At first I didnt really know what I was doing, but with more reading and exploration the game really. Questing is not just started by marked NPCs. A journal entry is made and you must read and explore on your own to get things done. Crafting also happens to be solved by exploring your ingredients. Simply by putting random herbs in a vial or special arrow heads onto a shaft, no crafting table or work bench required. The game makes you want to talk to everyone and has an interesting interaction between your two main characters through interactive conversations. This game is a great old school turn based rpg and the immersion makes you feel like you are in a very interaction DnD campaign.The only cons I can think of are the movement sometimes seems clunky and multiplayer is currently only 2 player. It seems that a mod is already in the works of changing the multiplayer to 4 players.Divinity: Original Sin is a must buy for any avid rpg player.

content:
ry 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								Update 6/28/2014Still in love with this game, awaiting release, the patch they released on Friday has added sounds and what not to the menu actions, and also managed to make the game run even smoother than it was before.I know it's not full release yet, but i've already clocked in 100+ hours into this game, and  awaiting my collector's edition, so yeah, this is bascially my GOTY 2014, 2nd only to Shovel Knight or something.Update 4/25/14: I LOVE THIS GAME! - The Loading issue has been fixed- The framerate is smooth as butter even with V-Sync on- And there have been a whole bunch of fixes and changes that only make me love the game more and more.Original Review:I'll be honest i'm really enjoying this game a lot, I keep coming back to it wanting to play more and more because it's so good, but then I remember it's in Alpha and the saves aren't always compatible so I end up not playing, but over all the gameplay feels pretty good, it's an isometric turn based RPG in the vein of Baulder's Gate or Fallout series, but there's a lot of details that make the game feel really good, for example, you can basically attack anything, if there's a barrel of oil and you use a fire spell on it, you can make it explode, also you can use those spells on doors, allies, or anything that glows red when you aim at it.Another great thing about this game is the humor, there's a lot of funny puns and diologue you'll find in this game that you won't see in other fantasy based RPG's, like putting a bucket over your head as a helmet, or being about to use a guitar as a weapon that actually has decent stats, I remember one time there was this monster called "adorable puppy", then when it got closer you realized it was a zombie dog, which kinda weirded me out. Also I can't forget the music, the music is pretty top notch, I'm not expert on music but basically I can sit in the menu or one place without even doing anything but sitting back listening to the music. That's not to say the game is without it's flaws, since it's still in Alpha, that means there's a lot of issues and bugs, i'll just list them.- The loading time at the beginning and when you load up the game is pretty long.- There's a lot of areas that haven't been added to the game yet.- The framerate stutters for me with V-sync on and in high settings, I know my PC can run it pretty well at it's best, but this feels like a game play issue, not one with my computer.- The game is only about 20% done, so sadly, there's a bit of a wait before getting the full experience...

Want to make a awesome club? get a branch and cover it with nails.At launch They will also be releasing a World/Adventure making editor to everyone who buys the game. This will add hundreds of hours to the game and give it a long life. For a Early Access this fun and bug free I have no choice but to recommend this game.-Ignious

You may be thinking the price is high for an alpha version of the game, but it is totally worth it. The future of this game is going to be an intense experience. If you like RPGs that are heavy on story and combat, this is the game for you. I strongly urge you check this game out, you will have no regrets. DillengerX Out!

								Real-time exploration combined with turn-based combat that is intuitive enough not to be a hassle every time you get into a fight. So far, this alpha build is already a good representation of what I expect from an RPG, having played games such as Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale and other Black Isle games in the day. The option to discuss amongst the party and shape the personalities of the characters is a great feature to enhance the immersion. 								Just how badly has modern game design softened your ability to be engaged in whats really going on in the story? The odds are quite a bit and this game will really show that. It's pretty refreshing to not have a quest marker, GPS tracker, arrow guidance or any quest helpers other then a detailed journal and common directional sense. Divinity Original Sin will allow you to once again be actually mentally engaged in the game in order to do progression rather then drudging through it like a undead. With very rich detail, an enthralling soundtrack and turn based combat, Divinity Original Sin will satisfy any real RPG fan.

content:
ber 9, 2015
												I have been a Divinity series fan ever since I played the first game as an Action/Adventure/RPG game. When I heard they did a Strategy/RPG game, I had my doubts about this game, but after buying it and playing it, I am a huge fan. Although the game play is different from it's counter parts, it's a nice touch and a nice change from the normal game play.This game plays a lot like "Baldur's Gate", only in true 3D. Overall, game play is done by a click of the mouse. Although there are keyboard commands, you can pretty much do the same thing using the mouse. Combat is pretty simple, you take turns making moves and choosing your attacks and then the enemy does the same. There's tons of quests and plenty of items to find and use throughout this game. Maps are very nice and big enough to do plenty of exploring.Here's my outlook of this game...PROS====-Plenty of character developement-Plenty of additional characters to find and bring with you to add to the party-Lots of spells and skills to learn and master (Your not just set with defaults, you can add more as you progress)-Tons of maps/locations to explore-You can reach well over Level 100+-With added skills and abilities, you can have well over 20,000+ HP-Gateways allow you to reach locations easily once you find them-Elemental effects that can change the tide of combat-Spells and skills that range from close combat attacks to the long range explosive fireball-Lots of NPC's to interact with and gain addtional questsCONS====- (When I find some I will let you know, most of the CONS I have read, I can't really fault that as part of the game itself. Some complained that there was too much dialog, and yet people always want a story. RPG's are designed to have long stories so I can't fault that to the developers nor the game, I like a good story in RPG games, otherwise there's no point in making RPG games. No story, no reason to be part of the game.)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
0, 2014
												It's been a long time since I've played an old school RPG of this quality. I highly recommend it to RPG fans! Here is my breakdown:THINGS THIS GAME DOES RIGHTCustomization - Instead of setting the length and thickness of your character's nose, you get options that matter, like choosing skills, talents, and stats which add up to make your own custom class. Of course, you can pick from a default list and build it however you want if you prefer. This is customization done right.Difficulty - This game will kill you. It's not Dark Souls hard, but it's hard enough to give you a sense of satisfcation when overcomingits challenges.Non-linearity - Aspects of this game are non-linear. Ultimately it does have a linear narrative, but you can almost completely freely explore the world. You're limited mostly by your level, which is the main barrier limiting progression.Grinding - Most RPGs allow you (or force you) to gain excessive amounts of experience to out-level the game's content. That is the fundamental principle of the JRPG. This game only gives you enough experience to survive the next challenge which ensures that the difficulty of the game is more fine tuned and harder to trivialize.Puzzles - Not everything is explicitly a puzzle. Sometimes advancing the story is a puzzle in itself (like the old adventure games). Sometimes a combat has puzzle elements. Sometimes it's just a room full of traps. Either way, there's almost always a problem to figure out.THINGS YOU MAY OR MAY NOT LIKESpeed of Play - This is a slow methodical game best spent enjoyed at a leisurely pace. The turn based combat, sprawling maps, and slower paced movement speed means that it'll take hours to progress through what some may consider a small amount of content. For the perceptive and the patient, though, that content has a lot to offer.Tone - It's a fairly straight forward fantasy setting. It's fun, whimsical, and self aware at times. It doesn't get overly dark nor overly comical. It's not too geneteric or creative. It serves primarily as a backdrop for the gameplay.Co-op Dialogue - You can do rock-paper-scissors to overcome disagreements. What you choose impacts your stats in small ways. Min-maxers beware. Everyone else; have fun.Random Loot - This has pros and cons. On the one hand, each playthrough is different. On the otherhand, a lot of loot sucks. It's debatable whether or not random loot works in a game with a limited pool of enemies.Nietzsche - He can join your party. It's pretty neat if you're in to that sort of thing. The devs didn't actually name him Nietzsche, but you'll figure it out if you went through that phase in your teen years.THINGS YOU PROBABLY WONT LIKEOops - It can be easy to make it hard or impossible to progress in the game by killing an NPC, letting them get killed, or just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ them off enough. Same goes for accidently clicking on an object or walking into a room that causes the entire town to aggro on you. Save often.Bugs - There's still quite a number of bugs, but they are very quickly being addressed. Still, be warned. Save often.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												Divinity: Original Sin is the greatest party based RPG to come out in years. It is a game that doesn't hold your hand; you can skip through dialogue with NPCs for quests but you won't get a quest marker, just a note in your log. You don't start off with crafting recipes, you have to read short entries in books to learn how to craft an item, and even then you won't see the recipe pop up in some sort of universal crafting list that counts your materials for you.It's a game that often time requires you to think if you want to progress in a quest. Many times I have advanced a quest simply by inserting myself in the situation - If I were in this world, what would I do next?You are challenged with harrowing bouts of turn based combat in which 4 characters you control ( 2 entirely player created, the others are companions ) and where every move you make is important, and every spell you cast, puddle of water you electrify or spill of oil you light aflame can turn the tide of a battle in your favor. The game has a fantastic system of being able to interact with the environment and create hazards to your advantage.The game is entirely cooperative, and the dialogue has a revolutionary system where coop players or your companions can challenge your word and you have to either reason, charm, or intimidate them into your way of thinking through a simple game of rocks, papers scissors. Should you fail this mini game, it would be like losing the argument and being swayed to your companion or friend's idea, and you have to do something entirely different. It's incredibly interesting and mimics the real word, where sometimes things don't go as exactly planned or you don't always get your way.The game has depth. There's so much to sink your teeth into, and you can easily put in over 60+ hours if you want to complete each side quest while taking your time. The world is so rich that I find myself speaking to every single named NPC just to get their take on the land, hoping they may have a story to tell that may better my understanding for a quest, or have a new quest to give.Oh - and the speaking. The voice acting is absolutely fantastic. The lines are somewhat sparse as dialogue with NPCs is mostly text based, but when you hear characters speak, they're well voiced with enthusiasm and a wide array of voice actors. It's a game that every gamer who appreciates an RPG should experience. You owe it to yourself. If you're thinking about buying it, do it.

content:
0, 2014
Early Access Review
								So I went against my own rule and bought an Alpha Early Access game on Steam. Divinity: Original Sin. I’ve had my eye on it for a long time, and they released a collector’s edition that comes with 2 copies of the game and both it’s predecessors, plus free launch DLC. So I caved. After playing the game, I definitely see why its still in early access and why save games won’t be carrying over to final release but holy hell is it fun. Its a very diablo-esque dungeon crawler but the combat is turn based, rather than real time and a lot of the different skills play off eachother. For example, I can cast a rain storm over the battlefield which puts out any fires and eliminates the burning status effect. Then my wife casts a chain lightning and it does increased damage to every enemy it hits because they’re in the rain. The combinations are all over the place: oil+fire, water+lightning, theres a bunch. I definitely recommend at least looking into it, if this piques your interest.

												This is a great effort by Larian worth any RPG fan's time.  I loved Baldur's Gate when it came out and haven't found anything that has captured its essence since quite like D:OS does.  Every system in place here is solid and ripe for improvement in future games.  Battle, crafting, skills, equipment, exploration, dialogue... all of these are fun and seem well thought out (though rock,paper,scissors for charisma/intimidate is just ok).  While there is quite a bit of freedom, players are still somewhat limited in where they can go based on level alone.  I accidentally went to the wrong area at one point, unaware why my %'s to hit were failing (it's level-based), and ended up at a large boss battle I couldn't win.  Luckily, the save & transportation systems made it easy to just go somewhere else.  I will say that the game got a bit repetitive for me once I found a combination of abilities that made all battles easy, but that didn't happen until 40 hours in, so I got my money's worth for sure.  I'm very much looking forward to what's coming next using this same game style.

content:
er 12, 2014
												Probably one of the best co-op experiences I've ever played.Wonderful throwback to old-school dungeoncrawl RPGs.If you and a friend are bored, look into buying the Collectors edition, You get 2 copies of the game. If you split the cost it is cheaper than buying 2 standard copies.When a friend and I first started, we ended up wandering into areas we weren't high enough level for, and got stuck on a few quests. Some people will probably find this frustrating. However, I found it be pleasantly refreshing. Too many game now a days just hold your hand through the whole game. It really made us think critically, and overall made it a more engaging experience.Graphics are well done, mechanics are well thought out. Decent story-line (Not great, but not bad either.) Voice acting could be a bit "cheesy", but I find it to be part of the charm. Just a wonderful game.9/10And always remember: "There is no one that has as many friends as the man with many cheeses."

content:
, 2014
												(09/10) - Near PerfectionWell...The graphics are just spectacular, the battle system is aswesome, the lore is interesting, the quests are well designed, the classes/enemies are nicely diversified, the environmental effects are perfectly implemented, the characters are intriguing, all animations look absolutely brilliant, the bosses are supberbly awesome, the difficulty can be set so the game is really hard and requires a lot of planing and tactics, the ai is good, the dungeons and in general the different ambients look very beautiful, the game is even more fun in coop and the entire experience can last a very long time...Other than the camera, to which you have to accustom yourself first, there is literally nothing bad in this game.Heck, i even spend 10 hours trying to solve the first main quest and never got bored even tho i never fought anything and had absolutly no action. It´s just done so well, that even i can loose myself in these brilliant shemes they call quests.If all dialogs would have been voiced over, this would have been the first game on steam, which i would rank with a 10/10.Thus "sadly" it caps at a 9.5 for me and an absolute recommendation for everyone owning steam... which is free, so: for everyone!

												Like Baldurs Gate 2. Drops you into a rich world of exploration and discovery.Good humor from developers. Indepth skill trees.Having fun so far. Quest givers are not very helpful and are somewhat cryptic. As you explore the game you will eventually stumble upon the quests you have been assigned to complete. A bit annoying but given the linear nature of the game, you're bound to finish it if you try to explore all the caves, nooks and secret hiding spots. Morality is an interesting concept here... you don't really want to steal everything in sight because it's the fastest way towards getting murdered by the quite overpowered town guards.Paid $40, felt i got my money's worth given the quality and entertainment endured.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
2, 2014
												This game is honestly... I... well, I can't really put it into words. Many people compare this to old-school RPGs like Neverwinter Nights, Baldur's Gate, and Ultima, and while I can honestly say I see the homage quite clearly, D:OS introduces many new concepts too. Co-op works seamlessly and flawlessly, the editor is great, and I can't wait to see what modders do with this game. My only main complaint about the game is the inventory system - it's a little clunky and hard to navigate at times, especially when you have a lot of items. The writing is clever and humorous, and I just found myself reading books and immersing myself in the world for hours on end - and I continue to do so as I play through the game.So, how do you know if this game is for you? Honestly, if you've enjoyed any old-school isometric RPGs in the past (or currently), chances are that you'll enjoy this game. For a newcomer to the genre of CRPGs? Watch a couple videos, if you have friends who personally like the game, shoot them a message and ask them why it's great. I also realize it's a pretty hefty price tag, but I honestly think it's worth it - especially with all that comes shipped with the game.

content:
, 2014
												I'm 26 years old. I've played RPG games all my life. I grew up playing games like Zelda, Diablo and Balder's Gate .etc. So, I feel pretty qualified to talk about RPG games :DDivinity: Original Sin is potentially one of the best RPG games of this generation. It is definately a 'classic', and I would say that it's (basically) the modern day equivelent of Balder's Gate.Let me put it plainly; if you like old-school role playing games like Diablo 1, Dungeons & Dragons, or Balder's Gate, then you *WILL* enjoy this game. No doubt. You will enjoy it even more if you have someone to play with too (the game supports two players, and you can either play on LAN, specific people over the internet, or in 'public games' on the internet where anyone can join) -- it really has something for everyone! (although i prefer to play solo, cos i'm an insocialable basturd xD)But yea, I don't usually buy games unless they're like -80% sale, but this one was definitely worth it. I've spent about 120 hours so far on this game, and I'm only like 10% through the game (I keep deleting and remaking my characters cos I'm very indecisive on what setup to play xD), so that's value for money!!I fully expect to spend over 1000 hours playing this game, since there is just so much content to explore and find... people to talk to, secrets to reveal... gawd I love this game :'DSeriously. Buy this game. Now. o__o

content:
ber 9, 2015
												I have been a Divinity series fan ever since I played the first game as an Action/Adventure/RPG game. When I heard they did a Strategy/RPG game, I had my doubts about this game, but after buying it and playing it, I am a huge fan. Although the game play is different from it's counter parts, it's a nice touch and a nice change from the normal game play.This game plays a lot like "Baldur's Gate", only in true 3D. Overall, game play is done by a click of the mouse. Although there are keyboard commands, you can pretty much do the same thing using the mouse. Combat is pretty simple, you take turns making moves and choosing your attacks and then the enemy does the same. There's tons of quests and plenty of items to find and use throughout this game. Maps are very nice and big enough to do plenty of exploring.Here's my outlook of this game...PROS====-Plenty of character developement-Plenty of additional characters to find and bring with you to add to the party-Lots of spells and skills to learn and master (Your not just set with defaults, you can add more as you progress)-Tons of maps/locations to explore-You can reach well over Level 100+-With added skills and abilities, you can have well over 20,000+ HP-Gateways allow you to reach locations easily once you find them-Elemental effects that can change the tide of combat-Spells and skills that range from close combat attacks to the long range explosive fireball-Lots of NPC's to interact with and gain addtional questsCONS====- (When I find some I will let you know, most of the CONS I have read, I can't really fault that as part of the game itself. Some complained that there was too much dialog, and yet people always want a story. RPG's are designed to have long stories so I can't fault that to the developers nor the game, I like a good story in RPG games, otherwise there's no point in making RPG games. No story, no reason to be part of the game.)

26, 2015
												Fantastically deep and challenging game in the style of Baldur's Gate and the great isometric RPGs of old. The puzzles are challenging, and unlike modern games, there's no hand holding to make them easier. The combat is rich and strategic. Most of all, the game changes based on the decisions you make with how you train your characters, how you approach quests, who's in your party, and more. The story is long and rich, meaning you'll easily get your money's worth on just the first playthrough; and because the game can be quite different each time you play, there's tons of replayability. Highly recommend this game to RPG fans.

content:
9, 2014
Early Access Review
								These guys KNOW how to do a Kickstarter campaign better than most any developer I've seen.  They constantly keep you in the loop about EVERYTHING they are doing and why and showing updated videos covering everything with superb answers to live questions.  It's been a thrill to watch this game come into being and it's the first one that has surpassed all my expectactions.  The Turn Based nature is so versatile, characters can be so unique, Co-Op is just way beyond what I would have expected and then even more beyond what I could have expected is the Editor that allows everyone to create their own games to freely share with others.  Not since Never Winter Nights have I see this attempted.  It's just amazing all they have been able to complete and I'm so happy to have been able to help Kick Start this wonderful achievement.   I'm still holding off to play more fully until the full release but from testing it all out regularly everything has been improved on steadily and I haven't come accross any  bugs personally.  It all looks beautiful and deep.  I've given to many Kickstarter Campaigns, but this one has really been the best by a long shot in covering all that a Kickstarter campaign should.  I hope many other developers go by their example.  While waiting I've just gotted into Divinity 2 which I somehow missed along the way and it's been a blast too!  Larian and CD Project are now my two favorite developers!  Oh and surely check out the Twitch TV interviews that go along with this game.  They are soo good.  One just uploaded on the 18th even.  But check out the ones before it if you have any questions because they go into great depth.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												Alright, so the amount of hours played is inaccurate because I have no internet most of the time, so I've actually played around 50 hours. I haven't yet played co-op, but I'm very excited to check it out.    +You can roleplay two characters and have them argue and decide through rock, pape, scissors.            ++The arguments your characters make change their personality and their personality traits give them bonuses to certain abilities and such.    +I really enjoy the turn based combat and ability points system.     +So many quests everywhere that aren't even required!!! EXPERIENCEEE    +A large variety of characters and creatures to fight and talk to.    +Pet Pal trait allows you to speak to animals which are very helpful for figuring out quests.    +A pretty interesting leveling system, though -I wish you got more skill points later on so all of my characters don't end up being completely well rounded without me having to save them, but that's not much of a negative, it's just a balancer.    +Lots of customization in character creation.    +SO MANY PLACES.    +Realistic environment effects that are interactive!!!    -I accidentally got an adorable dog killed by digging up a grave which spawned an undead that he tried to help me fight. :(    -I get the skillbook thing, but I do wish you could get some skills by leveling.    -Crafting is a little confusing, it would be cool if they could add in a quest about crafting.    -There are still a few bugs that need to be worked out, but it literally just came out of beta, so I don't actually mind at all.    -I wish there were more early game companions to choose from.All in all, it's SO MUCH FUN and totally worth it, this is the only steam game that I have ever paid more than $20 for.

content:
, 2014
												So many of the younger persons have been so spoiled growing up playing nothing but Diablo-like click fests, that they have no patience for a well thought out and deeper RPG experience.Divinity: Original Sin, is throwback to the golden era of the cRPG. The age before Diablo's success spawned a new type of RPG with the most important element removed or given a back seat - THE STORY! Not to mention a watered down version of RPG combat - the button mash.This game is nostalgic. It leaves me with a good feeling just thinking about returning to the game, and experiencing it with the attention and thought that it was designed for. There is great attention to detail, the writing is excellent and humor a fun diversion, and the combat forces you to think instead of like pointing at a group of monsters and clicking them to death.This is what a real RPG game is all about! The developers did an excellent job with this.

content:

SummaryA good game with some flaws and great cooperative play.GameplayGame features a simple yet powerful(tho still limited) and funny crafting system and you could completely ignore if you don't like crafting. Crafted items are comparable to found and sold by vendors ones.Combat is... well, almost perfect. AI is sometimes bugged, but devs constantly improve it. Main issue is lava - you could kill anything not invulnerable with it.Questing is fun, well written and diverse, however it seems last chapter was rushed till release as it contains a way less quests than 1&2 ones on bigger territory. Main story is bug-free, but some quests are uncompliteable at 2 & 3 chapters.Non-mage characters will probably face lack of different skills, while mages enjoy diverse and rich amount of spells, both harmful and helpful.ReplayabilityIn my opinion game features zero-to-none replayability cause there's no major game-changing choices you could make. Game is filled with plenty of minor ones but those only affect your end-game stats via so-called "traits" like compassionate or blunt.Co-opThe game is desinged for two players. Both of you could do everything, no limits, later on you'll be able to take control of additional henchmen. You could savely afk while your partner takes control of your character. Game poses options for you to play a rock-scissor-paper game when you can't agree on certain answer in dialogue.Last-battle You can't take evil side by killing Astarte. And tis battle is extremely easy even on hard, cause dragon is not immune to disables. Boring.

												I backed the project through Kickstarter and I can say I am more than pleased.After a few hours of intense NON-combat questing in the town I solved a few quests in surprising ways, had disagreements with "myself" that lead to new friends or foes, skipped questlines by pickpocketing the right people, crafted my first gear and ventured out of town for my first big fights. The implementation of co-op, the way that fights can play in turn-based mode while other party members venture the world in real time add another layer of depth and fun to the game. Together with  the classless system I am already contemplating which skill/ability combination I will try for my next playthrough !Highly recommended, a true RPG offering freedom, experimentation and challenge without holding your hand while never being obtuse or confusing.Highly recommended !

												Divinity: Original Sin (DoS) is an excellent rpg game. With stunning graphics, nearly endless choices, and lots of difficult, advanced battles, DoS is an epic rpg. NPC's show lots of personality, whether or not they repeat the same lines over and over. Dos allows you to interact with the environment. For example, if a wooden barricade is blocking your path, you can shoot fire at it, then make it rain to diffuse the fire to continue walking your original path. No game can be perfect, and DoS is no exception. Early progression can be difficult and long, and people that dislike turn based combat will likely dislike the combat sequences in the game. DoS is a top down, Open world Rpg Epic.

content:
y 7, 2015
												I've had a lot of fun playing Divinity as it reminds me of time spent many years ago playing old school Bioware Infinity Engine RPGs like Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale.  The engine, graphics, sound and production values are all triple-A quality (for a top-down RPG) which suprised me for a game that came out of a kickstarter campaign. The learning/difficulty curve seems about right (for a non-powergamer playing on normal), with the game being quite challenging at first but after a while the gradual pacing and steady level progression kept me wanting to play. Not to mention the decent exposition and story line that is well above par for the genre. The "classless" system works really well, providing a fair amount of freedom in shaping your source hunters throughout and allowing you to adapt playing style as you discover the magic and combat systems.  The turn based combat is really good, and will appeal to lovers of games like X-Com and Final Fantasy. Can't wait to try out co-op and highly recommend this game to RPG lovers.

There are no difficulty sliders to my knowledge, so the usefulness of your stats/skills/dps will all depend on your team's level versus the enemie's level. Overall combat is balanced pretty well, and can be just challenging enough to keep you on your toes.Cons:- Either I'm just tired or i honestly can't think of anyI've been having a blast with this game so far, it has turned out to be quite the adventure game. This game is a 10/10 for me and I definitely recommend it to any open-world adventure fanatic

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
9, 2015
												9.5 out of 10. Fantastic Game. As an avid Divinity Fan since Divine Divinity, I was excited when I first found out that Larian was going to release another Divinity Game. I played all the Divinity Games from Divine Divinity to Dragon Commander. It is very deserving to be Game of the Year.  I enjoyed this game as much as I enjoyed Skyrim when it came out. Pros: Excellent Turn-Base Combat: Ability to use your enviroment against your enemy is very unheard of in most RPG and how each monster has a specific weakness to a specific type of damage whether it be magical or phyiscally. It's a blast to expierment on what does more damages to what specific group of monsters. And a battle could be in your enemies favor one time and next it's in your favor. Same applies to them. Longvity of a game: So many quests to do, I don't even think I completed all the quests in my 140 hours of playing this game. Excellent StoryHumorous: Especially when you meet Bellegar. Character Interaction, to actually be able to interact with every character and barter with each one actually made me feel like I was really in the world, but I expected nothing less as all the Divinity series aside from Dragon Commanderr had that. No Class Roles: You may have to pick a class to start out with but you don't need to follow the layout. I started out as a Wizard but decided to turn into a Battlemage. Replayablity: Replaying a different class after finishing the game adds so much more replay value. Co-Op: It's so fun to play with a friend, I played with my ex when we were still together and we had a blast playing. Exploration: So much to explore and I highly recommend you explore each and every place of this game you can find secrets, new quests and even legendary items. Music: One Word: Masterpiece Kirill Pokrovsky who is the composer of all the Divinity Music is a master at his art. The music is so blended perfectly with the game and it's atmosphere that it really adds a whole new layer of depth to the game. I could listen to this soundtrack so much and never get tired of it. Cons:The only con I can think of is I wish crafting was more in depth, and more recipes. Crafting seemed pretty non-existing to me while I played and I only used it to craft magic lock. Better armormaking and weaponsmithing would be nice. Still a fantastic game and has overtaken Divine Divinity and Dragon Knight as my favorite Divinity games.  Buy it and play it especially with a friend, the cooperation part really makes this game so much fun. Side Note: Those who complain about the difficulty of this game, sure it is difficult to begin with but it's really easy to get stronger and beat even the most diffiicult battles. With so many quests to do especially without leaving the main city you can easily get to the level you need to be to fight the mobs you see. I know it was hard for me but after some questing and gearing up, I was able to compete against the mobs and if that's not your cup of tea you can always turn the difficulty down. And make sure you grab two more companions in Cyseal before adventuring out, unless you're doing lone wolf build.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												This is definitely the best RPG I've played in years. The game has very little hand-holding and it makes you have to figure out stuff on your own. Quests aren't simply little exclamation points over character's heads, you don't have to necessarily run back to town to "turn in" a quest, you're not given a little point on a map for you to follow. This game wants you to become invested in its world, and invested I have definitely become. In most RPG's I've played recently I know the names of like, maybe 2 NPCs, because if I need to go to them for some reason the game will say, in capital letters, "GO HERE AND TURN IN THIS SPECIFIC QUEST TO PROCEED." This game doesn't do that, it's not its style.The first main quest in the game is essentially a murder mystery, which might not sound too amazing on paper, but it's a fantastic starting point in the game because it forces you to become invested in the world by talking to all of the NPC's, learning their relationships, collecting clues, etc... Your journal in the game recounts what you've learned, but it doesn't make any of the deductions for your, it's up to you, the player, to deduce who you think is the murderer.This type of quest design pervades throughout the game. If you play this game you may become a little frustrated at first because of how used current gamers are to having their hands held, but if you persevere (and please don't use a wiki) then you will find one of the most immersive and enjoyable games you'll ever play.

NeutralPretty slow moving at the start of the gameThe game requires a reasonable amount of patienceNot a lot of direction in where to go / what to doCharacter and gameplay progression feels very unconventional. You have to take initiative to make sure you character is getting new skills and increasing in powerPositivesFeels like a proper RPGHeaps of freedom of choiceInteresting and varied character creationLots of fun skills/itemsCombat is really free-forming which is awesome. Rewards inventive/smart ability and item usageRewards explorationArt direction is solid, lots of interesting environments and maintains a consistent level of quality even with its unconventionally saturated colour palette Writing is pretty good, relatively interesting universe/storylineWriting also tongue-in-cheek (though perhaps a little too often)NegativesThere are times when you will probably need a walkthrough to progress because it is not clear how to progress otherwiseCombat often devolves into elemental ♥♥♥♥♥torm for lack of a better termSome of the combat scenarios will become more of a routine of using the same skills in orderCharacter balance is a little awkward at times. Trying to go into multiple specialties does not seem very effective and my rogue character (especially the invisibility spell) seemed pretty overpowered in the early stages of the game  Minor GripesIdle animations can make properly selecting targets in combat a painNon-grid-based combat can be finicky at timesCrafting could have been fleshed out a lot moreAlthough it's mostly just the nature of the type of game it is, the RNG in the combat can definitely be frustratingOverall, Divinity is a fantastic game and one of the best I have played in its particular genre. Just make sure you know what you are signing yourself up for!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
1, 2014
												The best RPG I've played in a very long time. The closest a video game can get to a pen and paper RPG, Chris and I spent our first 5 hours just wandering around town literally doing nothing but stealing paintings, talking to kittens, and occasionally massacring random villagers. There's a lot of humor, a million ways to play the game, great turn based combat that is definitely not overly easily or too hard. The co-op is the best I've seen in an RPG, you can each make independant decisions and actually have your characters argue ending in a game of rock paper scissors, the victor getting the final say. The game doesn't hold your hand at all, so expect to have to learn and be creative, just as you have to do in a pen and paper story. There's crafting thats entirely experimental that I can't find two online lists that have found all the same things because theres that much. It's classless so you can really make your own character who you want them to be. There's a huge long story to this game, but I've been completely satisfied with my purchase and excited for the rest of the game without even venturing very far from the first town. I highly recommend Divinity if you are a fan of RPGs.

												- Pros -*Combat rules very comparable to Dungeons and Dragons. (Attacks of oppurtunity, a stat comparable to initiative, and more)*A comfortable amount of flexibility for creation of your 2 main characters* Fun and relatively innovative conversation system based off of stats and skills you have invested in (Charm, intimidation, etc)*Future modifications could provide endless playability-Cons-*The multiplayers leaves a lot to be desired. From having to repeat it a few times I was uninterested by the beginning of the 2nd playthrough. All and all, the game is really entertaining. A solid 4/5 stars type game. I could really use more content that doesn't lock me into this main story. I recommend picking up the game.

content:
10, 2014
												Updated Review --I like it!To start with, the world is big, there's lot to do and see and, in some ways a bit too much - your quest log is going to get overwhelmingly full and you'll probably end up somewhere new wondering why the hell you're standing there and trying to remember what your original goal was five hours ago.It looks beautiful, almost too much as it can be very easy to overlook something visually and start wondering what's gone wrong. In particular the ALT key to show items on the ground doesn't show all items, just 'equipable' stuff it seems. Unfortunantly there doesn't seem to be a way to have those items always show either, so you'll be holding down alt a lot.The UI has seen quite a bit of improvement though there are still some bugs to work out, multiplayer even more so. Some examples are the combat log not scrolling, the dialogue not showing you what the other person selected in the log, and the combative dialoge forcing you to scroll up to see some of what was said. Those and a few other things could stand to be tweaked.Progression is a little different from many modern games - you wont get a bunch of points every level that make a little difference but just one every few levels that will make a big difference. This also means not screwing up what you choose is important as, so far, I haven't come across a way to respec. Which is a shame since you're probably going to regret a point or two.Combat is good but sloppy, you can pretty much count on setting things on fire you didn't mean to and having a spell hit a wall when it shows a hit. There's also something a little wacky about a few of the element interactions (fire not always exploding a poison cloud or fire healing a water enemy because it melted ice into a puddle are a couple of examples) - they may seem that way because it's all based on rolls but without the log showing all those odds it's a little hard to say for sure.Despite all that, causing a massive chain-reaction of explosions or stunning a whole group of people standing in water is a lot of fun and working all your party members strengths together to take down someone 5 levels higher than you is great. Even stubmling into a devistating ambush and being wiped out is amusing and reminds you to save often.The music included is fantastic too, though the provided soundtrack, if you got it, doesn't seem to include the full library that was apparently put into the game. I do hope even more music gets added at some point as well since their composer's illness cut into what had been prepared for the game.It's a great game and once the last of the bugs are squished, and Larian does tend to be very good about patching, this game will be amazing.Original Early Access Review --So far, so good!After the Dragon Knight games I was excited to hear something new was in the works. While it's not the same style of RPG, it's got a Baulder's Gate vibe that was still appealing enough to back it on Kickstarter. Indeed, as the crowd-funding went on and more details and goals were reached, it very much became a source of excitement for me.After playing though some of the Alpha I was encouraged. The UI had some rough spots, there were some very obvious bugs and some subtle ones but even the update to Beta included a vast array of improvments that left a much more polished feel.Obviously things are still going to change and I've held back from playing too much before the final version, but from what I've seen so far, if you enjoy a big RPG with what seems to be a delightful level of depth and want turn-based combat where stratedgy plays a real factor, it's certainly worth checking out.

, 2014
												Divinity: Original Sin is the greatest party based RPG to come out in years. It is a game that doesn't hold your hand; you can skip through dialogue with NPCs for quests but you won't get a quest marker, just a note in your log. You don't start off with crafting recipes, you have to read short entries in books to learn how to craft an item, and even then you won't see the recipe pop up in some sort of universal crafting list that counts your materials for you.It's a game that often time requires you to think if you want to progress in a quest. Many times I have advanced a quest simply by inserting myself in the situation - If I were in this world, what would I do next?You are challenged with harrowing bouts of turn based combat in which 4 characters you control ( 2 entirely player created, the others are companions ) and where every move you make is important, and every spell you cast, puddle of water you electrify or spill of oil you light aflame can turn the tide of a battle in your favor. The game has a fantastic system of being able to interact with the environment and create hazards to your advantage.The game is entirely cooperative, and the dialogue has a revolutionary system where coop players or your companions can challenge your word and you have to either reason, charm, or intimidate them into your way of thinking through a simple game of rocks, papers scissors. Should you fail this mini game, it would be like losing the argument and being swayed to your companion or friend's idea, and you have to do something entirely different. It's incredibly interesting and mimics the real word, where sometimes things don't go as exactly planned or you don't always get your way.The game has depth. There's so much to sink your teeth into, and you can easily put in over 60+ hours if you want to complete each side quest while taking your time. The world is so rich that I find myself speaking to every single named NPC just to get their take on the land, hoping they may have a story to tell that may better my understanding for a quest, or have a new quest to give.Oh - and the speaking. The voice acting is absolutely fantastic. The lines are somewhat sparse as dialogue with NPCs is mostly text based, but when you hear characters speak, they're well voiced with enthusiasm and a wide array of voice actors. It's a game that every gamer who appreciates an RPG should experience. You owe it to yourself. If you're thinking about buying it, do it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
9, 2015
												9.5 out of 10. Fantastic Game. As an avid Divinity Fan since Divine Divinity, I was excited when I first found out that Larian was going to release another Divinity Game. I played all the Divinity Games from Divine Divinity to Dragon Commander. It is very deserving to be Game of the Year.  I enjoyed this game as much as I enjoyed Skyrim when it came out. Pros: Excellent Turn-Base Combat: Ability to use your enviroment against your enemy is very unheard of in most RPG and how each monster has a specific weakness to a specific type of damage whether it be magical or phyiscally. It's a blast to expierment on what does more damages to what specific group of monsters. And a battle could be in your enemies favor one time and next it's in your favor. Same applies to them. Longvity of a game: So many quests to do, I don't even think I completed all the quests in my 140 hours of playing this game. Excellent StoryHumorous: Especially when you meet Bellegar. Character Interaction, to actually be able to interact with every character and barter with each one actually made me feel like I was really in the world, but I expected nothing less as all the Divinity series aside from Dragon Commanderr had that. No Class Roles: You may have to pick a class to start out with but you don't need to follow the layout. I started out as a Wizard but decided to turn into a Battlemage. Replayablity: Replaying a different class after finishing the game adds so much more replay value. Co-Op: It's so fun to play with a friend, I played with my ex when we were still together and we had a blast playing. Exploration: So much to explore and I highly recommend you explore each and every place of this game you can find secrets, new quests and even legendary items. Music: One Word: Masterpiece Kirill Pokrovsky who is the composer of all the Divinity Music is a master at his art. The music is so blended perfectly with the game and it's atmosphere that it really adds a whole new layer of depth to the game. I could listen to this soundtrack so much and never get tired of it. Cons:The only con I can think of is I wish crafting was more in depth, and more recipes. Crafting seemed pretty non-existing to me while I played and I only used it to craft magic lock. Better armormaking and weaponsmithing would be nice. Still a fantastic game and has overtaken Divine Divinity and Dragon Knight as my favorite Divinity games.  Buy it and play it especially with a friend, the cooperation part really makes this game so much fun. Side Note: Those who complain about the difficulty of this game, sure it is difficult to begin with but it's really easy to get stronger and beat even the most diffiicult battles. With so many quests to do especially without leaving the main city you can easily get to the level you need to be to fight the mobs you see. I know it was hard for me but after some questing and gearing up, I was able to compete against the mobs and if that's not your cup of tea you can always turn the difficulty down. And make sure you grab two more companions in Cyseal before adventuring out, unless you're doing lone wolf build.

A huge world where you can do so many things in many different ways, like crafting, blacksmithing, customize your skin, solve riddles, negotiate itens, make your build etc. etc. etc. The story is beautiful and well developed, it has so much to do with the things I like to read. I feel like since Final Fantasy VII I don't fall in love this way for a game... 10/10.

												If you have any doubts about gameplay and turn based combat, don't worry and get this game if you like RPG's.Pros:+ Innovative, engaging and entertaining combat system which you have to make a plan and have a decent strategy (I mean a real strategy, tanking with tanks and attacking from range with mages/archers is definitely not enough to win most of the battles.)+ Diversive path/build options, you can build your charecters however you want and it would work.+ Smooth gameplay, nice GUI (which could be little bit better) no bugs, no mess, no sloppyness. Everything has adjusted perfectly.+ Pretty funny. NPC's, dialogues, quests etc. there are moment that will make you laugh out loud.+ Nice graphics, wonderful music.+ Game does not hold your hand, thus enables you to feel accomplishment.Cons:- Looting, and crafting( which is pretty diversive) felt a bit dull and unsatisfactory.- The map is not that diversive and big in comparison with other RPG's.- Optimization could be better. Plenty of people (including me) suffers from low-FPS problems.- I hated Rock-Paper-Scissors which I happen lose more often than I win. So I hate it.That's all. In short, game is really wonderful and worth every penny.  Now I will head back to the game...

content:
4, 2015
												An epic RPG with a lot of player autonomy. Although there are some tutorials, this wonderful game takes a more classic approach and lets the player figure out most things on his own. To summarize:+ A great deal of content. I've played for about 100 hours and I haven't finished my first playthrough yet.+ Much player autonomy. You'll feel free to explore and learn about the world at your own pace.+ Investigating! You'll do a lot of detective work in your quests. You're a lot like an inquisitor, trying to find and destroy evil.+ A good story, with quite a few twists and surprises. + Wonderful, turn-based combat.- Not much character development. It's possible I may have been spoiled by modern RPGs, but I reacted badly to this.- A small of amount of audible dialogue. Most interactions are done through text. Many players are ok with this though.- Too much running sometimes. There is a fast travel system, but you'll often find that you have to run great distances, with nothing to do but wait until the characters reach the destination.

content:
, 2014
												A weekend's worth of gaming into this gem and all I can say is that this game has "it" in abundance. If you like RPGs and don't mind turn-based ones, you'll enjoy this one a lot.  The combat system reminds me of The Temple of Elemental Evil in some ways, which was (in my opinion) the best-ever interpretation of core D&D rules ever.  Having said that, the turn-based system is fluid and doesn't feel bogged down as some procedural combat games may be at times.The graphics are well done and the environment is interactive in unique ways.  I'm looking forward to what else can be done with this engine and this world. Well done, Devs.  People who enjoy RPGs: get this game and have some fun.

content:

												So many of the younger persons have been so spoiled growing up playing nothing but Diablo-like click fests, that they have no patience for a well thought out and deeper RPG experience.Divinity: Original Sin, is throwback to the golden era of the cRPG. The age before Diablo's success spawned a new type of RPG with the most important element removed or given a back seat - THE STORY! Not to mention a watered down version of RPG combat - the button mash.This game is nostalgic. It leaves me with a good feeling just thinking about returning to the game, and experiencing it with the attention and thought that it was designed for. There is great attention to detail, the writing is excellent and humor a fun diversion, and the combat forces you to think instead of like pointing at a group of monsters and clicking them to death.This is what a real RPG game is all about! The developers did an excellent job with this.

content:
1, 2014
												I am giving this game a thumbs up with a few caveats.  It is almost the gold standard for RPG of this kind.  It is well worth the money, I got 87 hours out of it and I didn't even complete everything.  It is a lot of fun and is a dynamic world.  For example in most games where you see backdrops of crates you can't interact with, in this game you can.  You can move them or set them on fire.  A door locked and can't find the key?  Bash or burn it down if you like.Anyway,  I would strongly reccomend that you wait at least 3 months after this game is released to buy it for the following reasons.  By this time I sure hope there are good walk-though guides available.The quests in this game are very old-school.  They do not give you a lot of hints and there in no guidance in the least.  Some of them may require that you find hidden switches and hit them in the right order.  You will not know how many hidden switches there are.  You might find three of them and try all combos and nothing happens.  Well you need to find the 4th switch and try again... maybe find the 5th one?One quest requires you to find a hidden object, this is a main quest so you have to do it.  This object is "somewhere" in a large forest.  You need a perception of like 12 to "see" it.  Stats are very precious and you generally are not going to be able to pump perception as other stats are FAR more important.   The only way I solved it was by finding a screen shot of the locaiton, then moving my character there, putting on all +perception gear I could find, and THEN drank a super preception potion and FINALLY I could "see" this huge mound of dirt that had the item I needed.It is stuff like this that pisses me off and really takes away from this game.  I would really like to know if people find stuff like this naturally without guides.  Other than stuff like that, this is a great game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
0, 2014
												It's been a long time since I've played an old school RPG of this quality. I highly recommend it to RPG fans! Here is my breakdown:THINGS THIS GAME DOES RIGHTCustomization - Instead of setting the length and thickness of your character's nose, you get options that matter, like choosing skills, talents, and stats which add up to make your own custom class. Of course, you can pick from a default list and build it however you want if you prefer. This is customization done right.Difficulty - This game will kill you. It's not Dark Souls hard, but it's hard enough to give you a sense of satisfcation when overcomingits challenges.Non-linearity - Aspects of this game are non-linear. Ultimately it does have a linear narrative, but you can almost completely freely explore the world. You're limited mostly by your level, which is the main barrier limiting progression.Grinding - Most RPGs allow you (or force you) to gain excessive amounts of experience to out-level the game's content. That is the fundamental principle of the JRPG. This game only gives you enough experience to survive the next challenge which ensures that the difficulty of the game is more fine tuned and harder to trivialize.Puzzles - Not everything is explicitly a puzzle. Sometimes advancing the story is a puzzle in itself (like the old adventure games). Sometimes a combat has puzzle elements. Sometimes it's just a room full of traps. Either way, there's almost always a problem to figure out.THINGS YOU MAY OR MAY NOT LIKESpeed of Play - This is a slow methodical game best spent enjoyed at a leisurely pace. The turn based combat, sprawling maps, and slower paced movement speed means that it'll take hours to progress through what some may consider a small amount of content. For the perceptive and the patient, though, that content has a lot to offer.Tone - It's a fairly straight forward fantasy setting. It's fun, whimsical, and self aware at times. It doesn't get overly dark nor overly comical. It's not too geneteric or creative. It serves primarily as a backdrop for the gameplay.Co-op Dialogue - You can do rock-paper-scissors to overcome disagreements. What you choose impacts your stats in small ways. Min-maxers beware. Everyone else; have fun.Random Loot - This has pros and cons. On the one hand, each playthrough is different. On the otherhand, a lot of loot sucks. It's debatable whether or not random loot works in a game with a limited pool of enemies.Nietzsche - He can join your party. It's pretty neat if you're in to that sort of thing. The devs didn't actually name him Nietzsche, but you'll figure it out if you went through that phase in your teen years.THINGS YOU PROBABLY WONT LIKEOops - It can be easy to make it hard or impossible to progress in the game by killing an NPC, letting them get killed, or just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ them off enough. Same goes for accidently clicking on an object or walking into a room that causes the entire town to aggro on you. Save often.Bugs - There's still quite a number of bugs, but they are very quickly being addressed. Still, be warned. Save often.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
9, 2014
												Do I recommend this?  HELL YES!This game is a mix of all the old school greats, Ultimas, Baldurs Gates, Torment, Fallout, etc.What I liked alot:Story - There is a huge fleshed out world, lots of lore, books, etc for those that choose to read everything. The actual main story was fleshed out and interesting, it made me want to finish the game to figure out what happened. World - The world was pretty cool, very detailed with little things hiding everywhere for you to find.  They rewarded people that where willing to go adventuring. Graphics - Graphics where great, I had everything maxed out and did't have any preformance issues or find a problem with anything.  There where several different tilesets as well, so the world didn't get boring for me on my run through the game. Spell System - The spells where great.  Nice visual effects, can be mixed and matched to create extra nice effects, ie Lightning + Water.  This aspect also made you more careful, because if your own guy was in the water.... you get the meaning :). You had to be somewhat intelligent about what you cast also, spell effects would cause things like line of site issues, etc.  Hard to heal people when you drop a fireball between you and them and the place goes up in smoke and fire! Comabt - I've read reviews about people complaining about the combat, but it's perfect for this game.  It's turned based, initiative style, there's numerous different ways to finish off encounters and fights. It was as good of a system as I could have asked for for a multi character party game while still maintaining control of each charcter with precision.  What I liked but I thought could use some more work: Character Progression/Building- This was a little confusing at first, I didn't know what did what, what was good, etc. I had to do a little research outside of the game, but once I god how it worked, understood what was important and not so much I was good to go.  It was pretty easy to build an uber party, basically my 2 casters would buff my 2 frontline guys and they would go and destroy everything. With that being said maybe the difficulty could have been a little harder?Questing - Questing was great, there was some awesome quests, things that made me laugh, etc.  Some of the quests where hard to figure out and I had to get help from outside resource sites with where to go next because there wasn't enough clues (for me anyhow) telling me where to go.  I'm not asking for a big arrow pointing to everything, but some  more direction would have been more helpful, either on the map or in the quest log. Puzzles - Some of these where downright hard/impossible. I found myself looking for help more then a few times with how to solve puzzles, especiallly the weight puzzle. I have no idea how anyone would ever figure that out (This is after I tried for over an hour). Just asking for some more direction.  Crafting - The crafting was awesome and vastly helped out once I figured out how to use it but some of the blacksmithing stuff vs crafting stuff didn't make sense.  Regardless, make one of your characters have level 5 Crafting and Blacksmithing by the end of the game if you can.  There's numerous resource sites for how to make stuff also as the in-game books can be confusing, and are not organized, etc.  All in all, this is a great game.  The 9/10 reviews are spot on and I would highly recommend it to anyone who is nostalgic for an old school RPG in todays clothing.  The developers did an amazing job, and hopefully they have an expansion out soon, I know I'll be buying it.

y 21, 2015
												This is a great effort by Larian worth any RPG fan's time.  I loved Baldur's Gate when it came out and haven't found anything that has captured its essence since quite like D:OS does.  Every system in place here is solid and ripe for improvement in future games.  Battle, crafting, skills, equipment, exploration, dialogue... all of these are fun and seem well thought out (though rock,paper,scissors for charisma/intimidate is just ok).  While there is quite a bit of freedom, players are still somewhat limited in where they can go based on level alone.  I accidentally went to the wrong area at one point, unaware why my %'s to hit were failing (it's level-based), and ended up at a large boss battle I couldn't win.  Luckily, the save & transportation systems made it easy to just go somewhere else.  I will say that the game got a bit repetitive for me once I found a combination of abilities that made all battles easy, but that didn't happen until 40 hours in, so I got my money's worth for sure.  I'm very much looking forward to what's coming next using this same game style.

content:
, 2014
												This is definitely the best RPG I've played in years. The game has very little hand-holding and it makes you have to figure out stuff on your own. Quests aren't simply little exclamation points over character's heads, you don't have to necessarily run back to town to "turn in" a quest, you're not given a little point on a map for you to follow. This game wants you to become invested in its world, and invested I have definitely become. In most RPG's I've played recently I know the names of like, maybe 2 NPCs, because if I need to go to them for some reason the game will say, in capital letters, "GO HERE AND TURN IN THIS SPECIFIC QUEST TO PROCEED." This game doesn't do that, it's not its style.The first main quest in the game is essentially a murder mystery, which might not sound too amazing on paper, but it's a fantastic starting point in the game because it forces you to become invested in the world by talking to all of the NPC's, learning their relationships, collecting clues, etc... Your journal in the game recounts what you've learned, but it doesn't make any of the deductions for your, it's up to you, the player, to deduce who you think is the murderer.This type of quest design pervades throughout the game. If you play this game you may become a little frustrated at first because of how used current gamers are to having their hands held, but if you persevere (and please don't use a wiki) then you will find one of the most immersive and enjoyable games you'll ever play.

content:
1, 2014
												The best RPG I've played in a very long time. The closest a video game can get to a pen and paper RPG, Chris and I spent our first 5 hours just wandering around town literally doing nothing but stealing paintings, talking to kittens, and occasionally massacring random villagers. There's a lot of humor, a million ways to play the game, great turn based combat that is definitely not overly easily or too hard. The co-op is the best I've seen in an RPG, you can each make independant decisions and actually have your characters argue ending in a game of rock paper scissors, the victor getting the final say. The game doesn't hold your hand at all, so expect to have to learn and be creative, just as you have to do in a pen and paper story. There's crafting thats entirely experimental that I can't find two online lists that have found all the same things because theres that much. It's classless so you can really make your own character who you want them to be. There's a huge long story to this game, but I've been completely satisfied with my purchase and excited for the rest of the game without even venturing very far from the first town. I highly recommend Divinity if you are a fan of RPGs.

												Divinity: Original Sin (DoS) is an excellent rpg game. With stunning graphics, nearly endless choices, and lots of difficult, advanced battles, DoS is an epic rpg. NPC's show lots of personality, whether or not they repeat the same lines over and over. Dos allows you to interact with the environment. For example, if a wooden barricade is blocking your path, you can shoot fire at it, then make it rain to diffuse the fire to continue walking your original path. No game can be perfect, and DoS is no exception. Early progression can be difficult and long, and people that dislike turn based combat will likely dislike the combat sequences in the game. DoS is a top down, Open world Rpg Epic.
